Award.AwardTitle: Probing New Physics in Galaxy Formation at Ultra-High Resolution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A wealth of exciting new observational projects promise to revolutionize our understanding of galaxy and star formation: from the LSST and Gaia measuring Milky Way stellar populations in game-changing detail, to the James Webb Space Telescope probing galaxies during cosmic "first light", while the Hubble telescope identifies the long-"missing" mass in the medium around galaxies. This project intends to run large-scale cosmological hydrodynamic simulations on Blue Waters to make detailed predictions and leverage these transformative observations. The simulations will support the Feedback In Realistic Environments (FIRE) project, a network of theorists at 13 institutions, including several NSF postdoctoral and graduate student fellows: this collaboration has developed new, fully-cosmological simulations of galaxy formation that explicitly follow a diverse range of physics.

This project will carry out novel studies of galaxy formation by running cosmological simulations on Blue Waters with unprecedented resolution and physics. The project run a large suite of cosmological simulations, targeting galaxies from the faintest dwarfs through the Milky Way, at the ultra-high resolution and realism required to leverage the next-generation of observations. The petascale resources of Blue Waters will allow the project to resolve each galaxy with ~1 billion particles and follow them self-consistently over their entire history in live cosmological settings. These simulations will model the physics of galaxy formation with unprecedented realism, uniquely incorporating not only all of the important stellar feedback mechanisms (radiation pressure, photo-heating, stellar winds, supernovae), but also magnetic fields, physical (anisotropic) Braginskii conduction and viscosity, passive scalar (metal) diffusion, and explicit, multi-wavelength radiation hydrodynamics. This represents the culmination of several years of work supported by NSF, and will be critical to enable the science of the FIRE project. The project will support an outreach component involving high school students and teachers, and undergraduate students, as well as a large science team using these simulations. The simulations will be used to make predictions specifically for next-generation observatories including (but not limited to): JWST, LSST, Gaia, and HST, in order to test theories of galaxy and star formation, constrain the origin of the heavy elements in the Universe, the re-ionization history of the early Universe, the effects of fundamental plasma physics in the circum and inter-galactic medium, and the nature of cold dark matter.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal supported a program to carry out novel studies of galaxy formation using cosmological simulations with unprecedented resolution and physics. We ran a large suite of computer simulations of how galaxies form, over cosmic time targeting galaxies from the faintest dwarfs through the Milky Way, at the ultra-high resolution and realism required to leverage the next-generation of observations. The petascale resources of Blue Waters allowed us to resolve each galaxy with ~1 billion resolution elements and follow them self-consistently over their entire history in live cosmological settings. When the interstellar medium (ISM) of galaxies is resolved into dense molecular clouds, massive stars naturally form and then inject large quantities of energy and momentum into the surrounding medium via "stellar feedback"; this feedback is critical to produce realistic galaxies and generate the powerful galactic winds observed, radically altering the baryon cycle between galaxies and the inter-galactic medium (IGM). These simulations modeled the physics of galaxy formation with unprecedented realism, uniquely incorporating not only all of the important stellar feedback mechanisms (radiation pressure, photo-heating, stellar winds, supernovae), but also magnetic fields, physical (anisotropic) Braginskii conduction and viscosity, passive scalar (metal) diffusion, and explicit, multi-wavelength radiation hydrodynamics. This represents the culmination of several years of work supported by NSF, and critically supported the science of the "Feedback In Realistic Environments" (FIRE) project (a theory network with collaborators at 13 institutions) and several NSF Postdoctoral and Graduate Student Fellows.

A wealth of exciting new observational projects promise to revolutionize our understanding of galaxy and star formation: from the LSST and Gaia measuring Milky Way stellar populations in game-changing detail, to JWST probing galaxies during cosmic "first light," while the Hubble COS instrument identifies the long-"missing" baryons in the IGM. Cosmological hydrodynamic simulations are the most powerful tools to make detailed predictions and leverage these transformative observations. Such simulations have advanced tremendously over the past few years, and now follow hydrodynamics with greatly improved accuracy while scaling to petascale machines. These new codes, applied to cosmological "zoom-in" simulations, for the first time allow us to accurately model effects such as magnetic fields, thermal conduction, and radiation transfer in a fully-cosmological context, while directly resolving the ISM of individual galaxies. We have exploited these advances to develop new simulations with greatly improved predictive power relative to previous work. Over the past five years, we have been leading the FIRE project: we have developed new, fully-cosmological simulations of galaxy formation that explicitly follow stellar feedback on the scale of individual star-forming regions. These pilot studies have demonstrated that feedback can resolve several long-standing mysteries in galaxy formation. This proposal allowed us to push the frontiers of galaxy modeling into the next generation on all key fronts: physics, numerical accuracy, and dynamic range. The simulations provided new predictions for the structure of dark matter in the faintest galaxies, the origin and dynamics of outflows and the baryon cycle, the multi-phase nature of the IGM and galactic "cold flows," the origin and formation of star clusters, and the effects of radiation on galaxy formation during the epoch of reionization. We used them to demonstrate new physics as well, such as the role of relativistic particles interacting with galactic magentic fields, may "change the story" in radical and unexpected ways.

The simulations also supported programs where non-astronomy high school students and undergraduates are involved directly in generating visualizations of simulations for planetarium shows, while high school teachers are trained to use the simulation data directly via interactive tools to build in-classroom demonstrations and videos illustrating key curriculum topics. Undergraduate computer-science students further utilized the simulations for further development of public, GUI-based apps to interact with astrophysical data sets. These programs have recently provided visualizations for planetaria, television shows, and nationally-distributed feature films. Our code GIZMO is public and used by multiple groups in non-astronomy fields; all new development of hydrodynamics algorithms and massively-parallel optimizations have been integrated into the public code for wider use.
